data.text: there is a big difference in gear requirements for bikepacking over touring. You can tour with bikepacking gear. You can't always bikepack with touring gear. Sure there's a spectrum there, but there are differences. If you build bikepacking routes and educate people on how best to tackle and prepare for those routes, having a vision of bikepacking vs touring and where the route lands on the spectrum matters. If you design and build bikes and components, the difference matters a lot. This isn't about gatekeeping. I certainly love to hear about people out riding their bikes overnight on adventures of any kind, but the argument of "bikepacking" and "touring" are the same thing and there's no need for delineation, is like saying there's no need to acknowledge MTBs are different and need different design implementations than road bikes.

data.text:
Except racing bikes downhill [and then XC] off road was a markedly different *sport* from before . BIkepacking however is about as old as bikes are. You see seat packs and frame bags on bikes a hundred years old. Which were ridden off or on crappy roads, because that was the norm then. Panniers became commonplace/fashionable and now bags on frame are fashionable again but as always with cycling panniers are coming back into fashion again. The Rough Stuff Fellowship in the UK did a lot of what you claim is the definition of bikepacking, long before the MTB was invented. Gatekeeping what bikes folk should ride or what kit they should use is not what we are interested in. If you object to folk using panniers or road bikes, then maybe join an elitist group where they sneer at such folk. The key thing to realise is that words change meaning. The word 'bikepacking' is not defined by Bikepacking*com, dictionaries go by common usage. People don't say cycle tour anymore, they bikepack. Also if you look at readers rig for bikepacking events on Bikepacking.com, you will find loads of bikes that do not fit the 'minimal/compact/light gear suggestion.

data.text: I understand you enjoy riding your bike regardless of whether it's "bikepacking," "touring," or randonneuring across country to play at bike polo matches between MTB races on your tall bike. Semantics aren't meant to be held as leverage, or exclude people, or talk down to people, or act as gate-keeping devices. There is simply a reason why the terms "bikepacking" and "touring" exist regardless of if people want to acknowledge the need for them or not. I worked 13 years as a Park Ranger helping folks plan all manner of adventures. I am an ambassador route creator with Ride with GPS, own a business that assists nonprofit public land organizations in creating cycling tourism opportunities, and contract with a number of major cycling component manufacturers to design and engineer touring and bikepacking goods. In this line of work whether you're creating gear, educating others on how best to navigate a route, or helping land managers build cycling experiences, it is important to have these terms at your disposal and understand their differences and the spectrum between them. Once again, I'm happy you like to go camping with your bike regardless of whether it's bikepacking or touring. What I don't like is folks demanding others treat those terms like their synonyms (or brands marketing everything as 'bikepacking' just because they think it will sell more).
